body: Actually, hold off for a bit. I'd like to update the README.md with the new information

@markusweimer  We can add an enum for the c# side (we have a constant for each runtime on the java side). The best place for that enum is probably Org.Apache.REEF.Common\Runtime.

WDYT?
That would be good. How do we make sure they are kept in sync between Java and C#?
This is a problem. Don't have a good solution for this. At this stage we will need to count on the fact that we usually don't change it and tests.
@markusweimer LMK if you think this solution is sufficient or you have better ideas.
Please add comments on both sides (Java and C#) such that we know not to break this when we touch it again in the future.

@shulmanb Thanks!

One concern: If a user of this new API specifies a runtime that isn't supported by the Java side (because it isn't configured), the error will only happen on the JVM side, right? Maybe we need to send the `MultiRuntimeDefinition` from Java to C# to make this better?
@markusweimer Not sure if it worth the effort. Probably not, as the error will be discovered in the base job testing phase anyway.

@markusweimer Also the behavior is similar between c# and Java, and the runtime name is validated only inside multi-runtime layer and not on the API invocation. So in both cases it will result in the same error in the same place. I actually think c# layer should not add any logic/validation beyond what is odne on teh java side.

> So in both cases it will result in the same error in the same place. 

Not convinced by that. @motus recently had to spend a week debugging and issue like that, where the Java side threw an exception that in turn crashed the bridge code, which to us seemed like a JVM crash. If this was pure Java, he'd have seen the exception.

In the case at hand, the behavior is in fact different. As a Java developer, I get a well-defined exception during development I can act on. As a C# developer, I have to hunt for the Java exception, which isn't my 1st hunch, delaying what would be a simple fix.

>  I actually think c# layer should not add any logic/validation beyond what is odne on teh java side.

That's fair. We could raise the exception on the JVM side and send it from there to the C# side. That way, we only need the validation code once, which is a win.
I've done a pass.
@markusweimer I would prefer not to delay on this, as this is not a trivial work item. Lets create a Jira for this. Do you agree? It shold probably be a generic Java/C# error handling jira.

Agreed that this is a more systemic issue than this PR. However, we could do the check based on a `MultiRuntimeDefinition` passed by Java as part of this PR and then mark that code with a `//TODO [REEF-XXXX]` to be removed once we have proper error propagation between the Java and C# side of the driver.
@markusweimer I don't see a good way to pass this definition to c# side. This is a runtime definition and currently c# code does not have it right?
How about adding a new call to the bridge `getMultiRuntimeDefinition()` which passes the `MultiRuntimeDefinition` from the JVM to the CLR as a `byte[]` generated by avro?

Maybe defining new avro object with just runtime names will be cleaner? To support in the same way all runtimes. Or even passing concatenated string? The real question is how the bridge code (on the java side) can know about currently provisioned runtimes.
@markusweimer Thanks for the review. I have addressed review comments.
No concerns raised, so I'll do one last test and merge.

> Maybe defining new avro object with just runtime names will be cleaner?

Maybe. But given that we already have the schema, I thought it would be easier to use that instead?

> Or even passing concatenated string?

Please don't. In the long run, we want to get rid of the current bridge and replace it with a two-process solution. The main communications channel between the two processes will be Wake, which exchanges objects serialized via Avro. Hence, even if it is just a list of strings, it would be best to have a schema for it.

> The real question is how the bridge code (on the java side) can know about currently provisioned runtimes.

`org.apache.reef.runtime.multi.driver.RuntimesHost` gets it as a named parameter, right? The same can be used for the Java bridge. I see two ways:
1. All the runtimes bind this parameter. That way, we can depend on it always existing.
2. Whichever class implements the Java endpoint to the bridge call gets two constructors. One which gets the parameter, another which doesn't. Tang will call the most specialized one.

In principle, the 1st solution seems better. The second one might be easier to build, though.
I'll also add restriction about Maven 3.3 or newer, while we're at editing our README.

I'm not sure this is a good solution.
This path is contained in variable `ThisNugetPackagePath` which is defined earlier in the same file and used in targets `PushPackages` and `CleanNugetPackages`. If the problem is that the variable is not available (being defined in a conditional block), it needs to be moved out of the block, so that `CleanNugetPackages` can also use its value. The proposed fix handles only one target.

Done with a pass. A general question: We validate these tests based on the logs they write, right? This shouldn't stop us from merging this, but we really should re-evaluate that choice. Testing on YARN this way would be way too slow.
It is true a lot of validation is based on the messages in logs. If we can come out any better way, we can change cross the board.

We have REEF-1147 for adding LocalAddressProvider. Does it make sense to split this change in two, one to add this functionality and second to actually configure tests?

@markusweimer the first test failure is a race condition that I'm currently investigating, which I believe is orthogonal to the change. It is caused by calling `Dispose()` on the `ContextRuntime` in the test, which causes an Exception if `CloseHandler` for Tasks is not bound. Whether or not this is expected, I am unsure, since it feels strange to dispatch a Task close event when `Dispose` is actually called on the Context. This does mirror the Java code, however. Note that if the close occurs between when the task is finished and when the `Failed` status propagates to the Task itself, an invalid transition may occur from `Done` to `Finished`. In other words, the following execution order will cause an invalid state transition:
1. Task completes, state not yet changed.
2. Close `ContextRuntime`, finds out task's `CloseHandler` not bound, throw an Exception, but Exception has not yet propagated upwards to change state to `Failed`.
3. Task changes state to `Done`.
4. Exception propagates upwards, state changed to `Failed`. Inconsistent state transition.
I'll file a JIRA item for this tomorrow.

The second test failure has actually been lying around for a while. For more details, you can see REEF-976 and its related sub-items.

Thanks!

@tcNickolas thanks for the verification! The test failure you posted is caused by the same issue as I posted above and is currently being addressed in https://github.com/apache/reef/pull/898. Another thing that may cause the the tests to fail to read log is likely because the `StopTask` tests don't have a test collection defined and hence it can run in parallel to the rest of the LocalRuntime tests. I believe it's also being addressed in another one of my PRs since it's only a one line fix.

@markusweimer I will go with the first approach. I will bind runtime names (one or more) for each runtime and inject this config to JobDriver, that will pass it to the evaluatorrequestorbridge. I am not going to use the MultiRuntime definition here, but will define additional avro structure that will contain only the runtime names.
